title: 106_hr90
content:
The Act is titled the "Stop Sweatshops Act" and any amendments or repeals mentioned in the Act refer to the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The Act also includes findings. The Congress finds that the production of garments in violation of minimum labor standards hinders commerce and fair competition, leading to poor working conditions in the domestic garment industry. Most sweatshop employers fail to comply with recordkeeping requirements under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The amendment of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is necessary to hold manufacturers accountable for compliance with wage and hour laws in the garment industry, promoting fair competition and better working conditions for workers. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to establish legal responsibility for compliance with wage and hour provisions in the garment industry. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to hold manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations. Manufacturers are civilly liable for violations of labor laws and subject to penalties for non-compliance. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to hold manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations, including cutting, sewing, dyeing, washing, finishing, assembling, pressing, or producing apparel. Manufacturers are civilly liable for labor law violations and penalties for non-compliance. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 holds manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations, including producing apparel such as clothing, knit goods, hats, gloves, handbags, hosiery, ties, scarves, and belts. The term 'contractor' refers to a person who contracts with a manufacturer to produce apparel, excluding pre-manufactured items. The term 'retailer' refers to a person engaged in selling apparel to consumers for personal use. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 holds manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations. The Fair Labor Standards Act holds manufacturers in the garment industry jointly liable with contractors for violations in apparel production. Manufacturers are also liable for violations committed by contractors in the production of apparel or components. Manufacturers in the garment industry are jointly liable with contractors for violations in apparel production. They can also be held liable for violations committed by contractors in the production of apparel or components. SEC. 4. RECORDKEEPING.

Penalties for failing to maintain payroll records as required under section 11(c) include a civil penalty of up to $1000 per employee for violations. Fraudulent submission of payroll records can result in penalties of $10,000 per act of fraud and $15,000 for a second offense.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act will be effective 30 days after its enactment.
